answers.author: Mark Kunkle
answers.text:
Ferguson Township is a home rule municipality in Pennsylvania and has three wards. The charter requires the wards to be reestablished every ten years based on the latest census data so that the population in each ward is "equal". With GIS it is a very simple exercise using the census data. I would recommend if you have a GIS technician on staff they could very well help with this process, if not you might consider a local college or University or your county GIS department for help.

answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
Ditto. When I was interning in Winchester, VA (25k), the Planning Director used basic GIS and the census block info to draw proposed adjustments to the boundaries of the four wards.
I like the university idea a lot. In 2011, student teams from Virginia universities competed to draw congressional and state legislative districts on principles of compact communities. The winning districts were actually filed as bills in the legislature. The skills are out there among faculties and students.
http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/virginia-politics/post/student-winners-named-in-college-redistricting-competition/2011/03/22/ABRDFZDB_blog.html

author: Cheryl Hilvert
text: A member has recently asked how local governments typically update their ward maps.  Particularly, he is interested in whether it is common practice to utilize a consultant for this service or if it is typically done internally.    Does anyone have any feedback on this question that I can share with this member manager?
title: Updating Ward Maps
